awd_titl_txt: Molecular and coding principles of perceptual learning
awd_abstract_narration: Learning and memory processes in the adult are diverse and rely on different brain structures. Adult perceptual learning allows an organism to survive by adapting its responses to salient sensory stimuli in its environment, such as salient sounds, and relies on intact function of the primary auditory cortex (A1). Neither the time course, nor the molecular mechanisms underlying this form of learning are currently known. Previous work supported by NSF showed that, unlike the current notions of A1 plasticity during auditory perceptual learning, the early stages are marked with a wide-spread reshaping of A1 with some areas of decreased, while others of increased responsiveness. Importantly, these opposing, but concurrently-occurring, changes rely on the learning-induced synthesis of a protein necessary for synaptic plasticity and learning, Arc. A primary goal here is to elucidate the molecular mechanisms of how Arc interacts with several other proteins to simultaneously direct these divergent changes.  The hypothesis is that decreased responsiveness is due to interactions with proteins that enhance endocytosis of receptors that increase synaptic excitability, while enhancement of responses is due to Arc's interaction with other proteins leading to dendritic spine reshaping. This idea will be tested by assessing the relative abundance of these proteins in areas with electrophysiologically-documented decrease or increase of responsiveness, respectively. Other predictions of the model will be tested by measuring the electrophysiological responses across A1 at different stages of learning. The data will be used to create a computational model of perceptual learning. The broader impact of this work includes involvement of minority undergraduates from several disciplines, as well as professional training of postdoctoral fellows. Developing a working team that includes students from several local universities will result in developing a public resource, a website with several age-appropriate sections that introduce cortical plasticity and cortically-supported learning and memory.

por.por_cntn:
Learning and memory are essential for survival as they allow proper interactions with our environment and help shape our psychological development. There are several different kinds of memory, subserved by learning-associated (plasticity) changes in different (but interacting) brain systems. One type is Perceptual learning, or the improved acuity in sensory tasks caused by experience which promotes survival of an organism by enabling adaptation of responses to sensory stimuli in its environment. Previous research, including ours, demonstrated that this learning depends on neuronal plasticity in adult primary sensory cortex. The prevailing dogma is that this plasticity develops linearly and strengthens over time with practice of responses to target sensory stimuli. The data we collected refute this dogma. We show that initially, after one day of training, the entire primary auditory cortex (A1) is in a state of hightened responsiveness to all auditory stimuli, and the responses to the target stimulus are not enhanced at all. Two additional days of task performance consolidate these changes, while additional training over two weeks reverses the responsiveness profile, such that the non -specific enhancement in non target areas of A1 is preserved, while the specific responsiveness of the target region to the target stimulus is increased and restored to pre training levels. Furthermore, we identified some key molecular players enabling this complex plasticity pattern. Arc, the product of a gene initiated immediately upon a plasticity-inducing stimulus, is not only necessary for the persistence (consolidation) of new perceptual memories, but it coordinates the overall changes in A1: promoting plasticity in some parts of A1 while inhibiting it in others. We further identified Arc’s molecular partners that allow this complex pattern of plasticity and demonstrated that Arc exerts its main effect during the early, but not late part of the training. Finally, we identified the role of a neuromodulator (acetylcholine) and its main receptors in shaping this plasticity. These findings stress the importance of early interventions during perceptual learning and identify possible molecular targets.

This funding had impacts beyond the scientific discoveries. It allowed rigorous training of a total of 13 learners from undergraduate to postdoctoral level who have significantly advanced their professional development and enriched the health professional and scientific workforce. Importantly, half (6) were from backgrounds underrepresented in neuroscience.

The scientific and leadership training that we provided included conceptualization of experimental design, application of the scientific method, problem solving, data analysis, productive team collaborations and near-peer mentoring which benefits students/learners regardless of which area of science or technology they choose to pursue as a career. Additionally, many of the bench methods that we instructed them in are applicable to many disciplines within the life sciences. Developing these skills positions them to be successful innovators and future leaders in the life sciences.

We also developed educational resources available to the public and future trainees. These include a website on the neurobiology of hearing: https://www.augusta.edu/mcg/discovery/bbdi/neuroscience-of-hearing/index.php which has 3 different and age-appropriate levels: K-5, 6-12, and college/graduate; as well as instructional materials for explaining the dynamics of immediate early gene expression and unbiased stereological analysis.
